channel.description: The politics, economics, science and statistical analysis of the games we play and watch

item.title: Parkour’s street stuntmen resent the sport’s new organisers
item.description: A SHIRTLESS man floats through the air, some six or seven stories from the ground. Behind him is the roof of a grubby block of flats. At least five metres (16ft) in front of him and a couple down is another building. Tucked like a diver, he leaps above the abyss, rolls into his landing and sprints away.

item.title: Can the marathon’s two-hour barrier be broken?
item.description: IT IS one of running’s three great barriers. The first, a sub-four-minute mile, was achieved in 1954 by Britain’s Sir Roger Bannister, on a gusty day at Oxford University’s dusty cinder track.

item.title: Why fans are riveted by Giancarlo Stanton’s race for seventh place
item.description: THE story of the 2017 Major League Baseball (MLB) season has been the home run. Just three years after a lull in run-scoring sometimes called the “little deadball era”, when offence hit its lowest mark since 1981, equilibrium has been restored almost exclusively on the back of the long ball.

item.title: The Cleveland Indians are great, not just lucky
item.description: BASEBALL is a sport in which it can be hard to tell the difference between lucky and good.

item.title: Sorry, Roger: Rafael Nadal is not just the king of clay
item.description: THE RACE is on. Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer, the two men who dominated men’s tennis from 2005-10, have enjoyed a startling resurgence in 2017, splitting the year’s four grand-slam titles.

item.title: Sloane Stephens shows you don’t have to be aggressive to win a major
item.description: IN A US Open women’s singles event full of upsets and surprises, the most unexpected outcome of them all was the success of the American contingent. For the first time in 36 years, all four of the semi-finalists hailed from the host country.

item.title: Cricket’s future belongs to all-star Twenty20 clubs, not countries
item.description: CRICKETING aficionados had expected a record-shattering deal, and they were right. On September 4th the Indian Premier League (IPL), a domestic tournament which uses the abridged Twenty20 (T20) format, announced that it had signed a five-year contract worth $2.55bn for its worldwide broadcasting and digital rights.

item.title: Is the Apple Watch now mightier than the bat?
item.description: AMONG the many traditions that players and coaches in North America’s Major League Baseball (MLB) have kept alive since the sport’s origins in the 19th century, perhaps the most devious is sign-stealing. Teammates routinely need to communicate on the field, above all so that catchers can tell pitchers what type of pitch to throw.

item.title: Diego Schwartzman, tennis’s smallest male star, is gaining stature
item.description: WITH FORMER champions Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, and Stan Wawrinka all missing from this year’s US Open, which began on August 28th, a throng of less-familiar names headed to Flushing with a chance to make a name for themselves.

item.title: Alexander Zverev could be tennis’s next star, despite his height
item.description: IT HAS been a while since men’s tennis last featured a rising star who had realised his full potential. In the era of the “big four”, in which Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray have dominated the sport like no previous quartet, there has been a steady stream of young contenders.

item.title: The Cleveland Cavaliers extract a king’s ransom for Kyrie Irving
item.description: “IF IT ain’t broke, don’t fix it,” the old adage goes.

item.title: Even with the ABBA format, penalty shootouts remain a lottery
item.description: ALTHOUGH social-media sites are usually ablaze with fury after a football cup final, it is rare that supporters on both sides direct their ire at the same target.

item.title: The EAGLE takes flight
item.description: WELCOME to the home page of EAGLE, the Economist Advantage in Golf Likelihood Estimator. EAGLE is a mathematical model of golf tournaments that measures every player’s chances of victory at every point in the event.

item.title: Why Neymar is different
item.description: POOR FC Barcelona. Four summers ago the club outfought all opposition to sign the golden boy of Brazilian football, a 21-year-old known only as Neymar. Details soon emerged of the financial acrobatics used to sign him up: his transfer fee was not €57m ($76m), as advertised to interested parties and tax collectors, but in fact €86m.

item.title: Jordan Spieth′s Open victory illustrates the perils of playing it safe
item.description: JUST three months ago, a veteran golfer approaching the age of 40, with a case full of trophies but bereft of a major championship victory, at last broke through to secure one of the sport’s four most coveted crowns.

item.title: Rugby union’s rules and regulations let the sport down
item.description: IT WAS a result that almost nobody wanted or expected. On July 8th, as the match-ending siren sounded in the third and final test of the British and Irish Lions’ tour to New Zealand, the scores were level at 15-15, meaning that the series had finished with a 1-1 tie.

item.title: Wimbledon’s rapid grass courts have been less speedy this year
item.description: OF THE many characteristics that make Wimbledon a unique event on the tennis calendar, its pristine, finely-mown grass courts are among the most prominent.

item.title: The cliché that tennis is a sport of matchups is probably right
item.description: ANGELIQUE KERBER’S (pictured, left) reign at the top of the world rankings for women’s tennis came to an end on July 10th, when Garbiñe Muguruza (right) of Spain knocked her out of Wimbledon in the fourth round.

item.title: Convincing injured tennis players to withdraw is a tricky matter
item.description: ON JULY 4th at Wimbledon’s All England Club, the first-round matches featuring Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic finished even sooner than fans of those two superstars had hoped.

item.title: The reigning NBA MVP may not have been as valuable as he looks
item.description: KEVIN DURANT got what he wanted. In his very first season after he abandoned the Oklahoma City Thunder to join the Golden State Warriors and form an unprecedented super-team, his new club romped through the playoffs, clinching its second title in three years on June 12th.
